resources.string: \tIn today’s time, biking is becoming a more common means of transportation than ever before. The number of bikers has grown significantly within the past few years: between 2000 and 2009, the number of regular bike commuters increased by 70% across the United States.

\tHowever, it is important not to rush into the stream of all the bikers around you before considering your safety. Biking can be just as safe as driving as long as you follow the laws and apply common sense. Here are 5 tips which should put you along the right path to a safe ride.

\tGeneral rules of the road from vehicular driving also apply to bicycles. They are considered road vehicles just like cars and trucks. Therefore, be sure to always: stop at a red light, stay within your lane, make a complete stop at stop signs, etc.

\tThis should be quite obvious: Always wear a helmet! When you first place the helmet on without snapping in the straps, it should wiggle with minimal movement when you shake your head. There should be two finger widths of space between your eyebrows and the rim of the helmet. Once you snap on the straps, they should form a Y-shape just below your ears. The helmet should feel comfortable yet snug.

\tWhenever passing a vehicle, always pass from the left (driver side). You\'re more likely to be within their field of view by not placing yourself into the driver\'s blind spot. This is critical. If you do the opposite and pass from the right, you will be in a dangerous position by being outside of the driver\'s view.

\tIf you are about to change into a different lane, be sure to look behind you before doing so. While looking back, try your best to continue biking in a straight line. Once you\'ve ensured that no car is near you, smoothly transition yourself into the next lane. The combination of looking back and biking straight is a technique that is sometimes known as “scanning”.

\tBe sure to properly place yourself in a lane. If a bike lane is available, use it! Your community designed them to keep bikers such as yourself out of harm\'s way. Otherwise, the law in most states is for bikers to stay as far to the right as possible. However, if the road is particularly narrow, do not be afraid to use the entire lane. Your safety is a higher priority than the convenience of vehicular drivers.
